brief_description: "Samaveshit Shiksha Yojana" aims to provide inclusive education support and special facilities to children with special needs aged 6 to 18 years studying in government schools from Classes 1 to 12.
detailed_description: The &quot;Samaveshit Shiksha Yojana&quot; introduced by the Department of Education, Uttarakhand, ensures that children with special needs (Divyang children) enrolled in government schools from Classes 1 to 12 receive equal and inclusive educational opportunities. Under this scheme, students are provided with escort services, home-based education, sports, exposure visits, girl-stipends, and free assistive devices based on their individual needs. Additionally, special camps are organized for the distribution of equipment.
benefits: Comprehensive Support: Provides various facilities like escort, home-based education, sports, and exposure visits. Financial Assistance: Offers a stipend specifically for girls with special needs. Free Equipment: Provides free assistive devices tailored to the needs of disabled children. Identification and Enrollment: Facilitates the identification of children with special needs (Divyang children) aged 6-18 years and their enrollment in nearby schools. Specialized Educators: Ensures identification is done by trained special teachers at the block level.
eligibility_criteria: The applicant must be a child with special needs. The applicant must be studying in a government school. The applicant must be in Class 1 to Class 12. The applicant must be between 6 and 18 years of age for identification purposes.

steps: Identification: Special educators working at the block level identify disabled children aged 6 to 18 years at the beginning of the academic session. Assessment of Needs: Camps are organized for the identification of children with special needs to assess their specific requirements for assistive devices. Enrollment: After identification, children are enrolled in nearby government schools. Device Distribution: Assistive devices are provided free of cost to disabled children based on their needs, often through organized distribution camps.
